title: Find your councillors | About | Gloucester City Council
text: ## Your local councillors represent you at the council Councillors make decisions about council services, represent your views, and help resolve local issues. Enter your postcode below to find out who represents your area. ### What do councillors do? Councillors represent you and your community at the council. They: * Make decisions on council services and policies * Represent your views and concerns * Help resolve issues in your local area * Work with local groups and organizations ### How to contact your councillor You can contact your councillor about: * Local issues and concerns * Council services * Planning applications * Community matters **Tip:** For routine council services (like bin collections or council tax), it's usually quicker to [contact the council directly](https://gloucester.gov.uk/contact).

title: Assisted Collections | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text: We may be able to provide a free assisted collection service if you need help to take your waste and recycling containers to the pavement because of mobility difficulties or an impairment and there is no one else in your household. ### üîÑ Assisted collection review **If you have received a review letter, we are aware that some residents didn't receive the form.** If you would like to continue with your assisted collection please email your collection address to [environment@gloucester.gov.uk](mailto:environment@gloucester.gov.uk) You do not need to complete the form on this page. ## Who is eligible ### ‚úì You may be eligible if: * You have mobility difficulties or an impairment that prevents you from taking bins to the pavement * There is no one else in your household who can help * You live in a property with individual bins (not communal bin stores) ### ‚úï This service is not available to: * Residents that use communal bin stores * The original person who applied for an assisted collection and is no longer living at the property * Residents that have restricted access for example caravan parks, narrow or private roads, steps or steep driveways, length of driveway or locked gates **Important:** If you are receiving assisted collections but no longer need the service, you must inform us as soon as possible. ## How to apply or cancel an assisted collection ### Apply online (quickest way) Online is the quickest way to apply or cancel an assisted collection. [Apply or cancel online ‚Üí](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/environment-waste-recycling/waste-recycling-street-cleaning/bins-recycling/assisted-collections/) ### üìû Other ways to apply or cancel Please phone us on **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)** if you cannot use the online service. ## Important information ### üìã Proof of eligibility We may ask for proof of eligibility and we reserve the right to suspend or withdraw this service at any time although we would notify you if the service was to be withdrawn.

title: Check your bin collection day | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text: Enter your postcode to find out which bins are collected when at your property. ## How to put your bins out **By 7am on collection day** Put bins out the evening before ‚Äî collections can start early **At the boundary of your property** Where your drive meets the pavement, or at your garden gate **Where crew can reach them** Crews cannot enter your property or open gates **Lid must close fully** Overfilled bins may not be collected **Bring back within 24 hours** Don't leave bins on the pavement after collection ## What if my bin isn't collected? **Check it wasn't refused** Was the lid closed? Was it in the right place? Wrong items inside? **Check for service updates** Bad weather or vehicle breakdowns can delay collections **Give crews until end of day** Crews can be out until 5pm, so your bin may still be collected **Report by 4pm the next business day** If still not collected, [report a missed collection](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/missed-collection.html) by 4pm the next business day and we'll return within 2 working days **‚ö° We'll return within 2 working days** after you report a missed collection. ## Set up reminders After looking up your collection days above, you can: * **Add dates to your calendar** ‚Äî Subscribe to an automatically updating calendar feed * **Email or SMS reminders** ‚Äî Get notified the evening before each collection * **Download PDF** ‚Äî Keep a copy of your collection schedule üí° **Tip:** Look up your postcode above to see reminder options for your address.

title: Apply or Renew an Extra or Larger Black Bin | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
You can get an extra or larger black bin if you're recycling everything you can by making full use of the recycling containers and if any of the following apply to you. ## Who is eligible ### ‚úì You may be eligible if: * **7 or more residents** registered at the property * **2 or more children under the age of 3** and still wearing nappies Have you heard about the [Gloucestershire Real Nappy Project](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/media/vlqbs2ce/gloucestershire-real-nappy-project.pdf) (PDF, 8.3 MB) * **Certain medical conditions** that generate additional waste ### ‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Before you apply **If you're having problems managing your waste and don't meet the criteria, please ensure you are making full use of the weekly recycling service.** For us to assess your application you must be recycling your waste by having a minimum of: * 2 recycling boxes * 1 blue sack * 1 large food caddy * 1 small food caddy Use our [order recycling container service](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/order-recycling-containers) to order boxes, lids, sacks and food caddies. ### üì∏ Photo evidence required You'll need to provide photos of your recycling on your recent collection day (remove lids so recycling can clearly be seen). ## How to apply or renew ### Apply online (quickest way) Online is the quickest way to apply or renew for an extra or larger black bin. [Apply or renew online ‚Üí](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/environment-waste-recycling/waste-recycling-street-cleaning/bins-recycling/apply-or-renew-an-extra-or-larger-black-bin/) ### üìû Other ways to apply or renew Please phone us on **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)** if you cannot use the online service. ## What happens next

### ‚è∞ Decision timeline We aim to provide you with a decision or correspondence within **6 weeks**. We may contact you for more information or a site visit may be required. **Until a decision is made it is your responsibility to manage your extra waste.** ### üí° Need help reducing waste? Most households can manage with a standard black bin by making full use of the recycling service. Check our [recycling guide](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/what-goes-where.html) to see what you can recycle. For families with young children, consider the [Real Nappy Project](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/media/vlqbs2ce/gloucestershire-real-nappy-project.pdf) which can help reduce nappy waste significantly.

title: Garden waste collection | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
Subscribe to fortnightly garden waste collection in a brown bin. We collect from February to November every year. ## Annual subscription ¬£60 per year üìÖ February to November (10 months) üóìÔ∏è That's about ¬£6 per month during the collection season ## What you get üóìÔ∏è ### Fortnightly collections Regular collections every two weeks from February to November üóëÔ∏è ### Brown bin provided 240-litre bin delivered free if you don't have one üìç ### Same day as black bin Collected on alternate weeks to your general waste ‚è∞ ### Collection window Collected between 7am and 6pm on your scheduled day ‚ùÑÔ∏è ### Winter break included No collections in December and January when waste is minimal ### üìå Important to know **The garden waste service runs annually from 1 February to 30 November.** The subscription is ¬£60 per season, and you can join at any time. Your collections will continue until the season ends on 30 November, then you can renew for the next season starting 1 February. ## How it works 1. **Subscribe online** ‚Äî Pay ¬£60 by card or Direct Debit 2. **Receive confirmation** ‚Äî We'll email you within 2 working days 3. **Get your brown bin** ‚Äî Delivered within 10 working days 4. **Put it out for collection** ‚Äî Same day as your black bin 5. **We collect it** ‚Äî Every two weeks, February to November 6. **Renew next year** ‚Äî We'll send you a reminder ## What we collect ### ‚úì You can put in your brown bin * Grass cuttings * Lawn clippings * Leaves * Small branches (under 10cm) * Twigs * Hedge trimmings * Plants & flowers * Weeds * Windfall fruit * Dead flower heads

### ‚úï Do not put in your brown bin * Soil or turf * Tree stumps or large branches * Japanese knotweed (invasive species) * Diseased plants (put in black bin to prevent spread) * Pet waste * Food waste (use your food caddy instead) * Plant pots, stones or gravel ### üè¢ Don't have a garden? You don't need to subscribe to this service. Use your food caddy for food waste and put houseplant cuttings in your black bin. ## Collection dates ### üìÖ 2025 season **Collections run:** 1 February 2025 to 30 November 2025 **Winter break:** December 2025 and January 2026 (no collections) **2026 season starts:** 1 February 2026 We don't collect in December and January because there's very little garden waste in winter. This also gives crews time for vehicle maintenance and helps reduce costs. **Your collection day:** Brown bin collection is on the same day as your black bin, but in alternate weeks. [Check your collection day ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/collection-day.html) ## üí° Composting at home You can reduce garden waste and create free compost by composting at home. It's better for your garden and the environment. * **Free** ‚Äî No subscription needed * **Good for your garden** ‚Äî Creates natural fertilizer * **Better for the environment** ‚Äî No transport needed * **Easy to get started** ‚Äî Simple once you know how [Guide to composting at home ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/composting-at-home) ## Common questions ### Can I have more than one brown bin? Yes. You pay ¬£60 for each additional bin. Subscribe for your first bin, then [order extra bins](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/order-bin) separately.

### What if I only want it for part of the year? The subscription covers the full season from 1 February to 30 November. We don't offer part-season subscriptions or refunds if you decide to cancel partway through. Consider whether you'll use the service for most of the season before subscribing. ### What if I move house? If you move within Gloucester, you'll need to take out a new subscription for your new address. The subscription is tied to the property, not to you personally. If you move outside Gloucester, the subscription cannot be transferred or refunded. ### What happens to my garden waste? It's taken to a composting facility where it's turned into soil conditioner used by farmers and gardeners. ### What if my bin isn't collected? Wait until the next working day (crews sometimes run late), then [report a missed collection](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/missed-collection.html). We'll return within 2 working days. ### Can I put garden waste in my black bin instead? You can, but your black bin is only collected every two weeks and may fill up quickly. Garden waste can also be composted at home for free.

title: Report a missed collection | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
We'll return within 2 working days to collect your bin. This service is quick and easy ‚Äî most people complete it in under 2 minutes. **All collections running normally** There are no reported issues affecting collections today. ## Before you report a missed collection **You can report a missed collection if:** * Your bin was due for collection today or yesterday * It's before 4pm on the day after your collection * You put your bin out by 7am on collection day * Your bin was at the edge of your property (where the crew could reach it) * The lid was closed and nothing was sticking out * You didn't have wrong items in your bin (this causes it to be refused) **‚è∞ Reporting deadline: 4pm the next business day** Crews update the system as they complete rounds. You can report a missed collection until 4pm the day after your scheduled collection. After that, you'll need to wait for your next scheduled collection. ### Your address Postcode We'll use this to find your address and collection schedule ### Which bins weren't collected? Select all that apply. You can report multiple bins at once. Loading your bins... ### A bit more detail Is there anything else we should know? (optional) This helps us resolve the issue faster. You don't need to explain where you put your bin ‚Äî we already know that. How would you like us to contact you? ## Report received Your reference number is: MB-2025-XXXXX ### What happens next **We'll return within 2 working days** (usually sooner) to collect your bin. Please leave your bin out until it's been collected. If we can't collect your bin (for example, if it contains wrong items), we'll let you know why. ## What if your bin was refused? If your bin has a note or sticker on it, it wasn't collected for one of these reasons: ‚ùå

### Wrong items inside Contaminated bins can't be collected. Check what should go in each bin. [What goes where ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/what-goes-where.html) ‚ö†Ô∏è ### Lid wouldn't close Overfilled bins or items sticking out prevent safe collection. üö´ ### Not accessible Bins behind locked gates or too far from the road can't be reached. ‚öñÔ∏è ### Too heavy Bins that are too heavy create a safety risk for collection crews. **What to do next:** Remove the problem items, then put your bin out on your next scheduled collection day. ## How to prevent missed collections üåô **Put bins out the night before** Collections can start as early as 7am ‚Äî don't risk missing your slot. üìç **Place at the edge of your property** Position bins where your drive meets the pavement or road. ‚úì **Make sure the lid closes** Don't overfill or force items in ‚Äî lids must close fully. üö™ **Keep it accessible** Crews cannot open gates or enter your property. ‚ôªÔ∏è üîî

title: All Your Bins & Containers | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
* **üÜï New to Gloucester? Get your first bins** All new residents receive a standard black bin for general waste. You'll need to order your free recycling containers separately. [Order your recycling containers ‚Üí](https://gloucester-self.achieveservice.com/service/Bins___Order_recycling_containers) * **‚ôªÔ∏è Order recycling containers** Free green boxes, blue sacks, and food caddies for all Gloucester residents. Each household should have a minimum of 2 green boxes and 1 blue sack. ##### Green boxes (2 minimum) For plastics, metals, and glass. Collected weekly. ##### Blue sacks For paper and cardboard. Can have multiple. ##### Food caddies Large outdoor caddy and small kitchen caddy. [Order recycling containers online ‚Üí](https://gloucester-self.achieveservice.com/service/Bins___Order_recycling_containers) #### üìç Replacement lids for green boxes Collect free replacement lids from our depot at 81 Eastern Avenue, Gloucester, GL4 6PG, or from Quedgeley Town Council. You cannot collect other containers from the depot. * **üóëÔ∏è Order or replace a black bin** If your black bin is damaged, stolen, or you need a replacement refuse sack, contact us by phone or online form. Phone: **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)** Or use the [Contact us form](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/contact) * **üìè Extra or larger black bin** Need more waste capacity? You may be eligible if you have 7+ residents, 2+ children in nappies, or certain medical conditions. [Check eligibility and apply ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/extra-or-larger-bin.html) * **ü§ù Assisted collections** Free service if you have mobility difficulties and cannot take bins to the pavement, with no one else in your household to help. [Apply for assisted collections ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/assisted-collections.html)

### üè¢ Flats & Shared Properties If you live in a flat or apartment, you'll likely have communal bins instead of individual containers. #### What you'll have * **Communal bins:** Shared recycling and waste bins in a designated bin store * **Food caddy:** Each flat gets a 7L kitchen caddy for food waste * **Communal food bin:** A brown 140L bin in the bin store for all residents #### Collection schedule for flats **Food waste:** Weekly collection **Recycling and general waste:** Fortnightly on alternating weeks #### Bin sizes for flats The number and size of bins depends on how many flats share them: * For every 8 flats: One 1100L communal bin * Recycling bins: 240L or 360L depending on the development #### Problems with communal bins? If your communal bins are: * Always full or overflowing * Damaged or need replacing * Not being collected properly [Call us: 01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396) ### üèóÔ∏è Developers & New Builds Information for developers, builders, and residents moving into new build properties. #### When will new properties get bins? Before bins can be delivered to new residential properties: * The property must be registered for Council Tax * The developer must request a site visit from our contractor * The contractor needs to agree that collections can be carried out safely #### üìã Planning & storage guidance for developers ‚ñº ##### Bin store requirements Developers must consider bin storage as part of planning submissions: * Collections can only be made from designated bin stores with adequate access * Under Building Regulations (2010) Part H: Householders must not carry waste containers further than 30m * Bin stores must be accessible for collection vehicles

##### Storage space calculations **For individual houses:** * 1 x 180L black bin (collected fortnightly) * 2 x green boxes for recycling * 1 x blue sack * 1 x outdoor food caddy **For flats/multiple occupancy:** * 1 x 1100L bin per 8 flats * 240L or 360L recycling bins as appropriate * 1 x 140L communal food waste bin per bin store ##### Contact for developers For full waste storage and collection guidance, download the [Waste & Recycling Storage Guidance (PDF)](https://www.gloucester.gov.uk/media/trqgrqer/waste-storage-and-collection-guidance-february-2020.pdf) To arrange a site visit: **[01452 396 396](tel:+441452396396)**

title: Household Recycling Centres | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
Household Recycling Centres (HRCs), sometimes called 'tips' or 'the dump', are for items that don't fit in your bins. All centres require you to book before visiting. ### üìÖ Booking required for all visits **You must book before visiting any Household Recycling Centre.** Book online at [Book your HRC visit](https://www.gloucestershirerecycles.com/household-recycling-centres-hrcs/car-and-van-bookings-for-hrc-visits/) Phone bookings: **01452 596 626** (weekdays 9am-5pm) for those without internet access ### üè≠ Your nearest centre ### Hempsted HRC (Gloucester) #### üìç Location Hempsted Lane, Gloucester #### üïê Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Closed:** Thursdays **Note:** Closed on Christmas Day, Boxing Day and New Year's Day ## All Gloucestershire Recycling Centres You can visit any of the five Household Recycling Centres in Gloucestershire. ### Fosse Cross HRC (Cirencester) #### üìç Location Fosse Cross, Cirencester #### üïê Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Closed:** Tuesdays ### Oak Quarry HRC (Coleford) #### üìç Location Oak Quarry, Coleford #### üïê Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Closed:** Tuesdays ### Pyke Quarry HRC (Horsley, near Stroud) #### üìç Location Pyke Quarry, Horsley, near Stroud #### üïê Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Closed:** Wednesdays ### Wingmoor Farm HRC (Bishops Cleeve)

#### üìç Location Wingmoor Farm, Bishops Cleeve #### üïê Opening hours **Summer:** 9am - 5pm **Winter:** 10am - 4pm **Open:** 7 days a week **Note:** This is the only centre open 7 days a week ## What you can take to recycling centres Household Recycling Centres accept a wide range of materials and items including: Garden waste Cardboard and paper Glass bottles and jars Plastic bottles and containers Metal cans and scrap metal Wood and timber Electrical items Batteries Textiles and clothing Books and media Household furniture Mattresses Fridges and freezers Paint and chemicals Rubble and soil (small amounts) Tyres (limited quantities) **üí° Tip:** For a complete list of what can and cannot be taken, and any restrictions or charges, visit [www.gloucestershirerecycles.com](https://www.gloucestershirerecycles.com/household-recycling-centres-hrcs/) ## Important information ### üöó Van permits If you're visiting in a van, pick-up truck, or large vehicle, you may need a permit. Check the Gloucestershire Recycles website for details. ### üè† Household waste only Recycling centres are for household waste only. Business and commercial waste is not accepted. ### üìã What to bring Bring proof of Gloucestershire residency (such as a utility bill or Council Tax letter) and your booking confirmation. ### ‚è∞ Allow enough time Booking slots are typically 15 minutes. Make sure to arrive on time and allow enough time to unload your vehicle safely.

title: What goes in which bin | Bins and Recycling | Gloucester City Council
text:
Getting your recycling right helps protect the environment and saves money. Use this guide to know exactly what goes in each bin. üîç ### Not sure what goes where? Use the Gloucestershire Waste Wizard to search for specific items and find out exactly how to dispose of them. [Search the Waste Wizard ‚Üí](https://www.gloucestershirerecycles.com/waste-wizard/) ### ‚úì What goes in Plastic bottles Plastic pots & tubs Plastic trays Metal cans & tins Aerosols (empty) Aluminium foil Metal lids ### ‚úï Do not put in Plastic bags Polystyrene Plastic film Black plastic trays Crisp packets **üí° Top tips** Rinse items and squash bottles to save space. Remove lids from plastic bottles ‚Äî metal lids can stay in, plastic lids go in general waste. ### ‚úì What goes in Glass bottles Glass jars ### ‚úï Do not put in Drinking glasses Pyrex or ovenware Window glass Mirrors Light bulbs Crystal **üí° Top tips** Rinse bottles and jars. You can leave labels on. Remove lids ‚Äî metal lids go in the other green box, plastic lids go in general waste. ### ‚úì What goes in Cardboard boxes Paper & writing paper Newspapers & magazines Envelopes Junk mail Greetings cards Cereal boxes Egg boxes ### ‚úï Do not put in Greasy pizza boxes Shredded paper Wallpaper Tissues or kitchen roll Glittery wrapping paper **üí° Top tips** Flatten cardboard boxes to save space. If cardboard is wet or has food on it, put it in your black bin instead. ### ‚úì What goes in All cooked food All raw food Plate scrapings Fruit & veg peelings Meat, fish & bones Dairy products Bread & cakes Tea bags & coffee Out of date food

### ‚úï Do not put in Any packaging Liquids or oil Pet waste **üí° Top tips** Line your caddy with newspaper or use free compostable bags from the council. Empty weekly to prevent smells. [Get free bags](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/compostable-bags) Everything that cannot be recycled. Because it's collected less often, recycle as much as possible to avoid your bin filling up. ### üìù Common items Nappies Sanitary products Plastic bags Polystyrene Cling film Tissues Crisp packets Pet waste (bagged) **üí° Top tips** Don't leave extra bags beside your bin. Check you're recycling everything possible. [Request an extra bin](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/extra-or-larger-bin.html) if you have a larger household. ### ‚úì What goes in Grass cuttings Leaves Small branches Hedge trimmings Plants & flowers Windfall fruit ### ‚úï Do not put in Soil or turf Tree stumps Japanese knotweed Diseased plants Pet waste Food waste ## Items that need special disposal These items cannot go in any of your bins. Take them to a recycling centre or arrange special collection. ### üõãÔ∏è Bulky waste Furniture, white goods, and mattresses need special collection. [Book a collection ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/bulky-waste)

## Why getting it right matters When you recycle correctly, you're making a real difference to the environment and your community. ‚ôªÔ∏è **Creates new products:** Recycled materials become new items instead of going to landfill üí∑ **Saves money:** Money saved on waste can be spent on other council services üåç **Protects the planet:** Reduces carbon emissions and helps fight climate change üë• **Creates local jobs:** The recycling industry employs people in our community **‚ö†Ô∏è Contamination wastes everything** When wrong items get mixed into recycling, entire loads can be rejected and sent to landfill. This costs money and wastes everyone's effort. [Learn more about contamination](https://gloucester.gov.uk/bins/contaminated-recycling)

title: Guildhall Events | Gloucester City Council
text: Hire the historic Gloucester Guildhall for your event, performance, or ceremony. ## About the Guildhall Gloucester Guildhall is a historic building in the heart of the city. It has performance and event spaces suitable for a range of activities. ## Suitable for ### Performances Concerts, shows, and theatre ### Conferences Business events and meetings ### Weddings Ceremonies and receptions ### Exhibitions Art and displays ### Ceremonies Civic and formal events ### Meetings Large group gatherings ## How to book 1. **Contact the Guildhall booking team** to check availability 2. **Complete booking form** with your event details 3. **Provide insurance** and risk assessment for your activities 4. **Get licensing if needed** for alcohol or entertainment 5. **Pay hire fees** before your event ## What you need Similar to other events on council property, you will need: * Insurance (public liability cover) * Risk assessment for your event activities * Licensing if selling alcohol or having entertainment (Temporary Event Notice or premises licence) * Compliance with capacity limits For availability, pricing, and bookings, contact the Guildhall booking team or the City Events team.

title: Events on Council Land | Gloucester City Council
text: ## About organising events You need permission from Gloucester City Council to hold events on council-owned land or property. This includes parks, open spaces, and council buildings. We help you plan safe events that work for everyone. Our team will guide you through what you need to do. ### Who can organise events Anyone can apply to organise an event, including: * Community groups and charities * Businesses and commercial organisers * Individuals planning celebrations ### How long it takes You must apply well in advance. The time needed depends on the size of your event: * **Small events** (up to 499 people) ‚Äì apply at least 3 months before * **Medium events** (500-2999 people) ‚Äì apply 3-6 months before * **Large events** (3000 or more people) ‚Äì apply at least 6 months before * **Street parties** ‚Äì apply 6-8 weeks before ## Popular venues * **Gloucester Park** Premier city park with 11 hectares of space * **Hillfield Gardens** Community park suitable for smaller events * **Barnwood Park & Arboretum** Green space with varied facilities * **Plock Court & Oxstalls Sports Park** Sports facilities and outdoor space * **Gloucester Guildhall** Historic building for performances and ceremonies **Check if your venue is available** Contact the City Events team at [city.events@gloucester.gov.uk](mailto:city.events@gloucester.gov.uk) or call [01452 396396](tel:+441452396396) ## What you need to provide All events need: * ‚úì Event application form * ‚úì Risk assessment * ‚úì Site plan showing event layout * ‚úì Public liability insurance (at least ¬£5 million) * ‚úì Temporary event notice if selling alcohol or having music

title: Events in Parks and Open Spaces | Gloucester City Council
text:
Get permission to hold an event on council-owned parks, open spaces, and public land in Gloucester. ## What you get * ‚úì Permission to use council land for your event * ‚úì Advice and guidance from the City Events Manager * ‚úì Assessment by the City Events Group * ‚úì Help with licensing and permissions * ‚úì Site inspection if needed * ‚úì Emergency contact support on event day ## Types of events we support ### Community events Festivals, fetes, and celebrations ### Sports events Tournaments and competitions ### Charity events Fundraising and awareness events ### Cultural events Performances and shows ### Music events Concerts and outdoor music ### Markets and fairs Craft fairs and markets ## Available venues * **Gloucester Park** Premier city park with 11 hectares of space. Includes cricket club, bowling club, skate park, and bandstand * **Hillfield Gardens** Community park suitable for smaller events * **Barnwood Park & Arboretum** Green space with varied facilities * **Plock Court & Oxstalls Sports Park** Sports facilities and outdoor space * **City centre open spaces** Various locations in the city centre **Check venue availability** Contact the City Events team at [city.events@gloucester.gov.uk](mailto:city.events@gloucester.gov.uk) or call [01452 396396](tel:+441452396396)

## How to apply 1. 1 **Contact the City Events team** Discuss your proposal and check venue availability 2. 2 **Complete Event Application Form** Fill in all details about your event 3. 3 **Prepare supporting documents** Risk assessment, site plan, and insurance certificate 4. 4 **Submit application** Email all documents to city.events@gloucester.gov.uk 5. 5 **Application reviewed** City Events Group will assess your application 6. 6 **Receive decision** We will tell you if your event is approved 7. 7 **Sign land use agreement** If approved, sign the agreement 8. 8 **Pay fees** Pay any fees and deposit before your event 9. 9 **Get licensing if needed** Apply for Temporary Event Notice if selling alcohol or having music 10. 10 **Pre-event site inspection** If needed, we will visit the site with you 11. 11 **Hold your event** Run your event safely 12. 12 **Clear the site** Remove all equipment and waste, return site to original condition 13. 13 **Post-event debrief** If needed, meet with us to discuss how it went ## How far in advance to apply ### Small events (up to 499 people) Events with up to 499 people and no amplified or live music Apply at least 3 months before your event ### Medium events (500-2999 people) Events with 500-2999 people or needing licensing Apply 3-6 months before your event ### Large events (3000+ people) Events with 3000 or more people Apply at least 6 months before your event ## What you need to provide

### 1\. Risk assessment You must assess all risks at your event. This includes: * Hazards during the event * Setup and takedown activities * Site-specific risks (slopes, water, roads nearby) * Weather risks * Crowd management * Emergency evacuation * Fire safety * Electrical safety * Food safety (if serving food) * First aid provision * Safeguarding (especially for children's events) * Accessibility ### 2\. Site plan You must provide a plan showing: * Event layout and where activities will be * Stages, stalls, marquees, equipment * Emergency vehicle access points (at least 3 metres wide) * Entrances and exits for people * Emergency evacuation routes * First aid points * Fire safety equipment locations * Toilets (including accessible toilets) * Lost children point (if family event) * Alcohol sale areas (if selling alcohol) * Food vendor locations * Generator and power supply locations * Parking areas * Barriers and fencing ### 3\. Insurance You must have: * **Public liability insurance** ‚Äì at least ¬£5 million cover. This protects against claims for injury, damage or loss to members of the public * **Employers liability insurance** ‚Äì at least ¬£5 million cover if you have paid staff or volunteers. This is a legal requirement ### 4\. Licensing (if needed) #### Temporary Event Notice (TEN) You need a TEN if you are: * Selling or supplying alcohol * Having live music, recorded music, or performances * Serving hot food or drink between 11pm and 5am A TEN costs ¬£21 and covers up to 499 people. Apply at least 10 working days before your event.

#### Premises Licence You need a full premises licence if: * You have 500 or more people at any one time * Your event is longer than 7 days * You are having more than 15 events per year at the same location Allow at least 3 months to apply for a premises licence. #### Music licensing If you have live or recorded music, you may need a licence from PRS for Music. Call 0800 068 4828. ## Your responsibilities ### Before the event * Apply 3-6 months in advance * Complete event application form * Provide risk assessment * Provide site plan * Get insurance (at least ¬£5 million public liability) * Apply for TEN or premises licence if needed * Contact PRS for Music if you have music * Tell local residents if your event will cause noise or disruption * Arrange staff and marshals * Book toilets, first aid, and waste collection * Arrange electricity if needed ### During the event * Supervise the event at all times * Keep emergency vehicle access clear (3 metres wide) * Manage crowds safely * Check site safety * Have emergency contact details available * Display your TEN if you have one * Make sure staff know emergency procedures ### After the event * Remove all equipment, structures and waste immediately * Return the site to how it was before * Tell us about any damage or incidents * Pay electricity costs if you used council electricity

## Staffing and security **General rule** You should have at least 1 event staff member for every 100 people attending. For example, if you expect 475 people, you need at least 5 staff members. You will need: * Marshals at road closure points, emergency exits, and crowd control areas * Security for larger events or where alcohol is served * Staff who understand emergency procedures, evacuation routes, and first aid provision **Safeguarding:** All staff and volunteers working with children must have appropriate checks, including DBS checks where required. ## Facilities you must provide ### Toilets You must provide enough toilets based on how many people will attend and how long your event lasts. You must provide accessible toilets. General rule: 1 toilet for every 100-150 people. More if you are serving alcohol. ### First aid You must provide first aid based on your event size and risks: * Small events ‚Äì first aid kit and trained first aider * Larger events ‚Äì first aid point, multiple trained first aiders, consider St John Ambulance ### Waste management You must provide: * Enough bins * Litter collection during the event * Site clearance after the event * Separate waste streams for recycling if possible ### Electricity If you need electricity: * It must be installed by a qualified electrician * Check with City Events team if council electricity supply is available * If using generators, include them in your risk assessment and site plan * You will be charged for electricity usage after the event ## What is not allowed **These items are not permitted at events:** * Sky lanterns and balloon releases * Bonfires on parks or verges * Metal detecting without permission * Fireworks without specific approval * Animals for entertainment (performing animals, animals in costumes, animal rides) * Hazardous materials ## Who can apply Anyone can apply, including: * Individuals * Community groups * Charities * Commercial organisations

### We cannot approve events that: * Are for political parties * Promote hatred or discrimination * Would cause unreasonable disruption * Cannot be made safe ## Costs There is a fee to use council land for events. The amount depends on: * Which venue or park you choose * How long your event lasts * What type of event (community or commercial) * How many people will attend * What facilities you need We may also ask for a damage deposit to protect against damage to the site. This will be refunded if you return the site in good condition. Payment is due before your event. ## Our service standards * We will reply to your first contact within 5 working days * We will decide on your application within 4 weeks of receiving all documents * Larger events may take longer if they need Safety Advisory Group approval * City Events Manager is available for advice before you apply * We will offer a site visit if needed * Emergency contact is available on event day

title: Privacy - Events on Council Land | Gloucester City Council
text:
How we use your personal information when you apply to organise events on council land or property. ## Who we are Gloucester City Council is the data controller for the personal information we collect when you apply to organise events on council land. **Data controller:** Gloucester City Council Eastgate Management Suite Eastgate Street Gloucester GL1 1PA ## What information we collect ### Venue availability queries When you ask about venue availability, we collect: * Email address * Event description * Preferred dates ### Event applications When you apply to organise an event, we collect: * Your name * Organisation name (if you represent an organisation) * Address * Email * Phone number * Event details (what, when, where, how many people) * Activities planned * Site plan * Risk assessment * Insurance certificate ### Safeguarding information For events involving children or vulnerable adults, we may ask for confirmation that staff have appropriate DBS checks. We do not ask for full DBS certificate details. ## Why we collect this information ### To provide advice on venue suitability and availability We need your contact details and event information to help you choose the right venue and check if it is available. ### To assess and approve event applications We need your event details, risk assessment, and insurance to make sure events can take place safely on council land. ### To coordinate with relevant teams We share your application with council teams (City Events Group) and sometimes with other agencies (Safety Advisory Group) to assess if your event can go ahead safely. ### To protect children and vulnerable adults We need to make sure appropriate safeguarding checks are in place for events involving children or vulnerable adults.

## Legal basis for processing We process your information because it is part of our public task as a council. This means we have a duty to manage public land safely. **Legal basis under UK GDPR:** Article 6(1)(e) - public task For safeguarding information (if we receive it), we also use: **Legal basis under UK GDPR:** Article 9(2)(b) - necessary for safeguarding purposes ## Who we share your information with ### Within Gloucester City Council We share your application with the City Events Group. This includes teams responsible for: * Festivals and Events * Asset Management * Environmental Health * City Centre Management * Open Spaces * Licensing * Health and Safety ### Safety Advisory Group (for larger events) For larger events, we share your application with: * Gloucestershire County Council (Highways) * Gloucestershire Constabulary (Police) * Gloucestershire Fire and Rescue Service ### Licensing team If your event needs a Temporary Event Notice or premises licence, we may share relevant details with our Licensing team. ## How long we keep your information ### Email enquiries about venues Email correspondence is kept in line with our standard email retention policy. ### Event applications We keep event applications for a set period. This period is currently being confirmed. ## Your rights You have rights under data protection law: ### Right to be informed This notice tells you how we use your information. ### Right of access You can ask for a copy of the personal information we hold about you. ### Right to rectification You can ask us to correct information that is wrong. ### Right to erasure In some cases, you can ask us to delete your information. We cannot do this during application assessment or during required retention periods for approved events. ### Right to restrict processing In some cases, you can ask us to stop using your information temporarily. ### Rights that do not apply #### Right to data portability This only applies when processing is based on consent or contract. Event applications are public task processing, so this right does not apply.

#### Right to object to processing This right does not apply to public task processing. We process event applications because it is our duty to manage public land safely. ## How to exercise your rights To exercise any of your rights, contact: We will respond within 1 month. ## Cookies If we introduce an online booking system, we will only use essential cookies to maintain your session during the application. We will not use analytics or marketing cookies. ## Complaints If you are unhappy with how we handle your information, you can complain to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). ## Updates to this notice We may update this privacy notice from time to time. Check this page for the latest information.

title: Street Parties and Road Closures | Gloucester City Council
text:
Get advice and support for organising a street party on a residential street in Gloucester. ## What is a street party A street party is a simple neighbourhood gathering where residents come together to celebrate on their own street. Typical street parties have: * Tables and chairs in the street * Less than 200 people * Only residents and invited guests * No ticket sales * No commercial stalls * No large structures like stages or marquees * Held in daylight hours * Finishes by 10pm ## Suitable streets ### Good for street parties * ‚úì Quiet residential streets * ‚úì Cul-de-sacs * ‚úì Streets with low traffic ### Not suitable for street parties * A or B roads * Bus routes * One-way streets * Major through-routes * Streets where closure would cause significant traffic problems ## Road closure **Important** Road closures are processed by Gloucestershire County Council, not Gloucester City Council. Gloucester City Council can provide guidance, but you must apply to the County Council for the road closure. ### How long in advance to apply Apply for road closure at least 6-8 weeks before your street party. ### Road closure signs You must put up 'Road Closed' signs at both ends of your street. You can: * Borrow signs from the council (check availability) * Hire signs from sign companies * Buy signs from suppliers (around ¬£50 each) * Make banners (must be clearly visible) ### Emergency vehicle access You must keep a clear path at least 3 metres wide for fire engines and ambulances to get through if needed. ## What you need to do

### Before the street party * **Tell your neighbours** ‚Äì Give written notice to all nearby residents about your plans. Tell them the date, time, and how long the road will be closed. Include your contact details for questions * **Apply for road closure** ‚Äì Apply to Gloucestershire County Council at least 6-8 weeks before * **Get signs** ‚Äì Arrange 'Road Closed' signs for both ends of the street * **Consider a Temporary Event Notice** ‚Äì If you are selling or supplying alcohol, you need a TEN (¬£21) * **Consider insurance** ‚Äì Public liability insurance is not legally required for simple street parties, but you may want to get it. If you do, get at least ¬£5 million cover ### During the street party * **Display road closure notice** ‚Äì Show the official notice from the County Council * **Put up signs** ‚Äì Place 'Road Closed' signs at both ends of your street * **Put marshals at closure points** ‚Äì Have people at both ends to guide traffic and help residents who need to drive in or out * **Keep emergency access clear** ‚Äì Make sure emergency vehicles can get through (at least 3 metres wide) * **Allow resident access** ‚Äì Let residents drive in slowly with a walking marshal if they need to ### After the street party * **Remove signs and decorations** ‚Äì Take down all signs, barriers and decorations * **Clear all rubbish** ‚Äì Clean up the street * **Reopen the road** ‚Äì Make sure the road is clear for traffic again ## Alcohol and licensing ### If drinks are free You do not need a licence if drinks are genuinely free. ### If you are selling drinks or tickets include drinks You need a Temporary Event Notice (TEN) if: * You are selling alcoholic drinks * Tickets to your event include drinks A TEN costs ¬£21 and must be applied for at least 10 working days before your event.

### Music You usually do not need a licence for background music at a street party. If music is the main feature of your event, you may need a TEN or a licence from PRS for Music (call 0800 068 4828). ## Food You do not need to register for food hygiene for a one-off street party where residents are sharing food. You must make sure food is: * Prepared safely * Stored safely * Handled by people following basic hygiene practices ## Insurance Public liability insurance is not legally required for simple street parties. Low-risk street parties that are carefully planned have very little risk of liability claims. If you decide to get insurance, you should get at least ¬£5 million cover. This may cost ¬£50-100 depending on your event size. Neighbours can split the cost between households. ## Get help ### Gloucester City Council We can provide advice and guidance about street parties. * Email: [city.events@gloucester.gov.uk](mailto:city.events@gloucester.gov.uk) * Phone: [01452 396396](tel:+441452396396) ### Gloucestershire County Council For road closure applications, contact the County Council Highways team. Visit: [www.gloucestershire.gov.uk](https://www.gloucestershire.gov.uk/) ### Useful websites * [streetparty.org.uk](https://www.streetparty.org.uk/) ‚Äì Street party guidance * GOV.UK ‚Äì Your guide to organising a street party

title: Leadership and Structure | Your Council | Gloucester City Council
text:
Gloucester City Council is led by elected councillors and supported by professional officers who work together to deliver services and make decisions that affect our city. ## At a glance 39 Councillors 16 Wards 10 Cabinet Members ## Civic Leadership ### Ancient offices dating back over 800 years The Mayor and Sheriff are ceremonial roles with deep historical roots. The Sheriff was established by King John's Charter in 1200, making it nearly 500 years older than the City Council itself. The first recorded Mayor was Richard the Burgess in 1228. #### üëë The Mayor (545th) **First citizen of the city** - Chairs Full Council meetings and represents Gloucester at civic, ceremonial and community events. Appointed annually by councillors, the Mayor is a non-political role focused on civic duties. _Current: Councillor Ashley Bowkett (2025)_ #### üõ°Ô∏è The Sheriff (895th) **Deputy Mayor and historic office** - Vice-chairs Full Council and accompanies the Mayor on formal occasions. Originally collected taxes and presided over courts; now a ceremonial role preserving 825 years of Gloucester's history. _Current: Councillor Linda Castle (2025)_ **üí° Did you know?** Gloucester is one of only 15 UK towns and cities that have retained the ancient office of Sheriff, alongside York, Oxford, Canterbury, and Nottingham. ## Political Leadership ### Elected by residents The council is made up of 39 elected councillors who represent the city's 16 wards. Councillors are elected every four years to make decisions on behalf of residents and champion local issues. #### üèõÔ∏è The Leader The Leader is elected by councillors and is responsible for the council's overall direction and leadership. The Leader appoints the Cabinet and represents the council publicly. #### üë• The Cabinet The Cabinet is made up of up to 10 councillors, each with responsibility for specific areas like housing, environment, or finance. They make most major decisions. #### üó≥Ô∏è Full Council All 39 councillors meet regularly as Full Council to make key decisions including setting the budget, agreeing major policies, and appointing committees.

#### üîç Overview & Scrutiny Scrutiny councillors hold the Cabinet to account, review decisions, and investigate issues that matter to residents. [View Leader and Cabinet](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/councillors-and-wards/leader-and-cabinet.html) [Find your councillor](https://gloucester.gov.uk/about/councillors.html) ## Officer Structure The council employs around 400 professional officers to deliver services and provide advice to councillors. Officers implement the decisions made by councillors and ensure services run smoothly. #### Chief Executive The Chief Executive is the head of paid service and leads all council officers. They ensure the council operates effectively and delivers on its priorities. #### Corporate Management Team Senior directors responsible for different service areas such as communities, place, and resources. They manage teams and budgets. #### Service Managers Managers lead specific services like planning, housing, environmental services, and customer services. [View senior officer pay](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/how-were-organised/senior-pay-and-staffing.html) ## How Decisions Are Made The council makes decisions through various meetings and committees: * **Cabinet** - Makes most major decisions on services and policies * **Full Council** - Sets the budget and agrees the policy framework * **Planning Committee** - Decides planning applications * **Licensing Committee** - Makes decisions on licences for taxis, alcohol, and entertainment * **Overview & Scrutiny** - Reviews and challenges Cabinet decisions * **Audit & Governance** - Ensures financial controls and good governance

### Public participation Most council meetings are open to the public. You can attend in person, watch online, or even speak at certain meetings to share your views. [Learn how to have your say ‚Üí](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/have-your-say) [View meeting calendar](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/calendar.html) [Read our constitution](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/how-were-organised/our-constitution.html)

title: Meeting Calendar | Your Council | Gloucester City Council
text: ## View upcoming council meetings All council meetings are open to the public unless stated otherwise. You can attend in person, watch online, or view agendas and minutes. ### Full meeting calendar For the full interactive calendar with all meetings, agendas, and minutes, visit our democracy pages: [View full calendar on democracy.gloucester.gov.uk](https://democracy.gloucester.gov.uk/) ### Key Meeting Types #### Full Council All 39 councillors meet to make key decisions including setting the budget and agreeing major policies. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Cabinet The Cabinet makes most of the council's major decisions on services and policy. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Planning Committee Decides on planning applications that can't be decided by officers. **Frequency:** Usually fortnightly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm #### Overview and Scrutiny Committee Holds the Cabinet to account and reviews council policies and decisions. **Frequency:** Usually monthly **Time:** Typically 6:00pm ### Attending Meetings * **In person:** Most meetings are held at the Eastgate Management Suite, Eastgate Street, Gloucester GL1 1PA * **Online:** Watch live meetings on [our YouTube channel](https://youtube.com/@GloucesterCityCouncil) * **Speak at a meeting:** [Learn how to have your say](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/have-your-say/speak-at-a-meeting.html) ### Agendas and Minutes All meeting agendas are published at least 5 working days before the meeting. Minutes are published after the meeting. [Search agendas and minutes](https://gloucester.gov.uk/your-council/meetings-and-decisions/agendas-minutes.html)
